Award.AwardTitle: Enabling Next Generation Quantum Dot Emitters via Correlated Photophysics and Atomic Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professors Sandra Rosenthal and James McBride at Vanderbilt University to accelerate the development of sub-microscopic crystals of semiconductors, or quantum dots. These structures emit light and are used in diverse applications such as solid state lighting and displays and labeling of biological structures for analysis using microscopy. The PIs have developed a new characterization method to determine how the efficiency of light emission from a quantum dot is correlated to its atomic structure. The ultimate goal is to optimize the light emission of quantum dot systems that do not utilize toxic lead and cadmium. As a part of this effort, the growing field of nanotechnology is being introduced to the next generation of scientists through undergraduate research opportunities and outreach activities for rural middle-school students.

The proposed work is to synthesize cadmium free, colloidal core/shell nanocrystals and to characterize their ensemble charge carrier dynamics using femtosecond fluorescence upconversion spectroscopy. In parallel, the best performing structures will be identified by correlating fluorescence dynamics at the single nanocrystal level with the same particle's atomic structure and chemical composition determined using high resolution high angle annular darkfield scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) in conjunction with energy dispersive spectroscopy mapping (STEM-EDS) utilizing Vanderbilt's Tecnai Osiris. The information gained through the ensemble carrier dynamics and the correlation study provides a target to improve the current synthesis methodology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Colloidal quantum dots are nanosized semiconductors that can emit very pure colors of light when stimulated electrically or by UV-light. Up until the past few years, the best performing colloidal quantum dots have typically contained the heavy metal cadmium while alternative, heavy metal-free materials such as InP have struggled to compete in areas such as photostability, color purity and efficiency. This award enabled research to help understand at the atomic level, the structural origins limiting InP quantum dots. Utilizing advanced analytical electron microscopy coupled with single particle luminescence, we directly revealed how the diverse structures synthesized perform at the individual level. Additionally, subtle chemical intermixing during the synthesis was detected in the final quantum dot material leading to new insight on their formation and potential avenues for improved function. Ultimately, InP quantum dots with thick shells of ZnSe were synthesized with improved photostability and high color purity. Advanced analytical electron microscopy was also utilized to reveal chemical dynamics at different time points in the synthesis of graded thick-shelled quantum dots. The chemical imaging clearly showed predicted chemical reactivity is not adequate to describe the final structures grown in classic ?one-pot? quantum dot syntheses. Outside the lab, graduate students involved in this research and supported by this award also spearheaded outreach activities that reached, on average, 3400 students and laypeople per year in the Middle Tennessee region. Hands-on science lessons were employed to raise awareness and participation in STEM fields, especially among underserved and rural student populations.
